column1: #text=A clementine ( Citrus ×clementina ) is a hybrid between a mandarin and a sweet orange , so named in 1902 . [ 1 ] The exterior is a deep orange colour with a smooth , glossy appearance . Clementines can be separated into 7 to 14 segments . They tend to be very easy to peel , like a tangerine , but are almost always seedless when grown commercially ( unfertilized ) . For this reason they are sometimes known as seedless tangerines ; the clementine is also occasionally referred to as the Moroccan clementine . [ 2 ] They are typically juicy and sweet , with less acid than oranges . [ 1 ] Their oils , like other citrus fruits , contain mostly limonene as well as myrcene , linalool , α-pinene and many complex aromatics . [ 3 ] It is called Cantra in India

#text=Most sources say that the clementine came to exist because of accidental hybridization , with the first fruits discovered by Father Clément Rodier ( after whom the fruit was named in French and then English ) in the garden of his orphanage in Misserghin , Algeria . [ 4 ] However , there are claims it originated in China much earlier ; one source describes it as nearly identical to the Canton mandarin widely grown in the Guangxi and Guangdong provinces in China . [ 5

#text=The clementine is not always easy to distinguish from varieties of mandarin oranges . [ citation needed ] As such , it should not be confused with similar fruit such as the satsuma or honey sweet orange , or other popular varieties

#text=This variety was introduced into California commercial agriculture in 1914 , though it was grown at the Citrus Research Center ( now part of the University of California , Riverside ) as early as 1909 . [ 6 ] Clementines , usually grown in Algeria , Tunisia , Spain , Portugal , Morocco , Greece , Italy , Israel , Lebanon , Iran and Turkey , have been available in Europe for many years . A market for them in the United States was created when the harsh 1997 winter in Florida devastated domestic orange production , increasing prices and decreasing availability . [ citation needed ] Clementines are typically sold in net bags contained in small wooden or cardboard boxes in United States . [ 7 ] They sell in large numbers from mid-November through January , giving them the nickname " Christmas oranges " in some markets

column1: #text=Clementines lose their desirable seedless characteristic when they are cross-pollinated with other fruit . To prevent this , in 2006 growers such as Paramount Citrus in California threatened to sue local beekeepers to keep bees away from their crops
